questions.text: A 23 y P2L2 comes to the OPD. She says that she missed her period by 10 days and is now complaining of spotting. There is also mild abdominal pain. On examination the uterus is 6 weeks size and the os is closed. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Threatened abortion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A threatened abortion is characterized by vaginal bleeding and mild abdominal pain in early pregnancy, with a closed cervical os and an intact pregnancy. These symptoms indicate a potential risk of miscarriage, but the pregnancy has not yet ended.
  • ➤ threatened abortion

questions.text: A 26y old gives a history of two 1st trimester abortions following delivery of a preterm baby at 30 weeks due to severe preeclampsia. She is anxious and wants to be evaluated preconceptionally. Which of the following investigation will you advise?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lupus anticoagulant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APLA) should be suspected in women with recurrent first-trimester abortions and preeclampsia leading to preterm delivery before 34 weeks. Diagnostic evaluation includes testing for lupus anticoagulant, anti-cardiolipin antibodies, and beta-2 glycoprotein I antibodies.
  • ➤ Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APLA)

questions.text: All the following are risk factors for developing cervical insufficiency except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Endometrial biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cervical insufficiency can result from procedures that damage or remove portions of the cervix, such as conization, dilatation and curettage, or trachelectomy. Endometrial biopsy , however, does not affect the cervical tissue and is not a risk factor for cervical insufficiency.
  • ➤ Endometrial biopsy

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents for a routine checkup. She has a sedentary lifestyle, and her BMI is 26. She used to smoke 1 pack/day but has recently stopped. She was advised calcium and vitamin D supplementation at her last checkup but has not been taking these. She has no significant medical history. A DEXA scan is done, which shows her T score as -2.5. What is the most appropriate treatment option for her?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bisphosphonates

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bisphosphonates are the first-line treatment for postmenopausal women diagnosed with osteoporosis (T-score ≤ -2.5). These medications reduce bone resorption and increase bone density, significantly lowering the risk of fractures. Calcium and vitamin D supplementation is essential as an adjunct therapy but not sufficient as standalone treatment for osteoporosis.
  • ➤ Bisphosphonates

questions.text: Which is incorrect regarding Hormone Replacement Therapy in menopause?

options.label: A
options.text: It is effective for vasomotor symptoms during perimenopausal period

options.label: B
options.text: It should be given for young women with premature menopause

options.label: C
options.text: It is useful for primary prevention of heart disease

options.label: D
options.text: Cyclical HRT is preferred over continuous HRT in perimenopausal women

questions.correct_answer: C. It is useful for primary prevention of heart disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is useful for primary prevention of heart disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HRT should not be used for the primary prevention of cardiovascular disease due to its association with an increased risk of heart attacks and strokes. It is primarily used to relieve menopausal symptoms and in specific cases such as premature menopause.
  • ➤ HRT should not be used for the primary prevention of cardiovascular disease

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida at 36 weeks complains of decreased fetal movements since 1 day. The following test was ordered. What is this test?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Non-Stress Test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Non-Stress Test (NST) is a non-invasive method to monitor fetal heart rate patterns in response to fetal movements. It is commonly used in the third trimester when concerns about fetal well-being arise, such as decreased fetal movements.
  • ➤ Non-Stress Test (NST)

questions.text: A 22-year-old G2P1 with a history of a previous term stillbirth is now 37 weeks pregnant. She complains of decreased fetal movements for 2 days. A Biophysical Profile is ordered. All are components of the Biophysical Profile except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Umbilical Artery Doppler

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Biophysical Profile (BPP) consists of five components: fetal breathing movements, fetal movements, fetal tone, amniotic fluid volume, and the non-stress test (NST). Umbilical Artery Doppler is not a part of the BPP but is a separate test used to assess placental blood flow.
  • ➤ Biophysical Profile (BPP)
  • ➤ Umbilical Artery Doppler

questions.text: A 26-year-old lady with mild pre-eclampsia presents at 32 weeks. On abdominal examination, the uterus corresponds to 28 weeks, and the fetal heart rate is 132 bpm. An ultrasound is advised. The following image shows an umbilical artery Doppler. What is your interpretation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Absent diastolic flow

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of fetal growth restriction and placental insufficiency, absent diastolic flow in the umbilical artery Doppler is a concerning finding. It often indicates that delivery should be considered, especially if the gestational age is beyond 34 weeks, or if the fetus shows signs of distress.
  • ➤ absent diastolic flow

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman has been taking Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs) regularly for the past two years. She presents to the family planning OPD on Day 8 of her cycle with the complaint that she has missed taking two pills on Day 7 and Day 8. What will you advise her?

options.label: A
options.text: Take the last missed pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining packet

options.label: B
options.text: Take the missed pill as soon as possible and offer her emergency contraception also

options.label: C
options.text: Take the missed pill as soon as possible and use additional contraception for 7 days

options.label: D
options.text: Take the missed pill as soon as possible, use emergency contraception and discard the remaining packet

questions.correct_answer: A. Take the last missed pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining packet
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Take the last missed pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining packet

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For women who miss one or two pills , they should take the missed pills immediately and continue with the regular schedule without needing additional contraception. Only if three or more pills are missed is there a need for extra precautions, such as additional contraception or emergency contraception, depending on the timing of the missed pills.
  • ➤ one or two pills
  • ➤ take the missed pills immediately

questions.text: All are true regarding postpartum contraception except:

options.label: A
options.text: With full or near full breast-feeding, 70% of women remain amenorrheic through 6 months

options.label: B
options.text: With partial feeding or no breast feeding, a contraceptive method should begin during the 3rd postpartum week

options.label: C
options.text: The progestin only minipill does not affect lactation

options.label: D
options.text: The vaginal ring can be used effectively in breast feeding mothers as absorption of estrogen is minimal and does not affect lactation.

questions.correct_answer: D. The vaginal ring can be used effectively in breast feeding mothers as absorption of estrogen is minimal and does not affect lactation.
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Estrogen-containing contraceptives , including the vaginal ring, are generally not recommended during breastfeeding because they can reduce milk production. Progestin-only methods are the preferred choice for postpartum contraception in breastfeeding women.
  • ➤ Estrogen-containing contraceptives
  • ➤ not recommended during breastfeeding

questions.text: An intrauterine pregnancy of approximately 10 weeks gestation is confirmed in a 30-year-old gravida 5, para 4 woman with an intrauterine device (IUD) in place. The patient expresses a strong desire for the pregnancy to be continued. On examination, the uterus is 10 weeks in size, and the string of the IUD is noted to be protruding from the cervical os. The most appropriate course of action is:

options.label: A
options.text: Leave the IUD in place without any other treatment

options.label: B
options.text: Leave the IUD in place and start prophylactic antibiotics

options.label: D
options.text: USG to rule out ectopic pregnancy

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Remove the IUD immediately

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of intrauterine pregnancy with an IUD in place, the IUD should be removed as soon as possible if the strings are visible and accessible. This minimizes the risk of miscarriage, infection, and preterm labor. If there is any concern regarding ectopic pregnancy, an ultrasound should be performed to confirm the intrauterine location of the pregnancy.
  • ➤ IUD should be removed as soon as possible

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with infertility and is diagnosed with anovulatory cycles. Which of the following medications can be used for ovulation induction in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Both clomiphene citrate and letrozole
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Both clomiphene citrate and letrozole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Both clomiphene citrate and letrozole are effective medications for ovulation induction in women with anovulatory infertility. Clomiphene acts by blocking estrogen receptors, while letrozole reduces estrogen production, both leading to increased FSH release and stimulation of ovulation.
  • ➤ clomiphene citrate
  • ➤ letrozole
  • ➤ ovulation induction

questions.text: Match the following drugs used in gynecology with their corresponding indications:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A-1, B-2, C-4, D-3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea. Pelvic ultrasound reveals an intramural fibroid measuring 3 cm. The woman desires medical management rather than surgical intervention. Which of the following would be the most appropriate first-line drug in this woman?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Antifibrinolytic with NSAID

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For the first-line medical management of heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea due to fibroids, antifibrinolytics combined with NSAIDs are effective and well-tolerated. These treatments reduce menstrual blood loss and alleviate pain, offering a non-surgical option for symptom control.
  • ➤ antifibrinolytics
  • ➤ NSAIDs

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the OPD with amenorrhea of 6 weeks. Her urine pregnancy test is positive. A transvaginal ultrasound is done, which shows a normal uterus and adnexa. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pregnancy of undetermined location

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A pregnancy of undetermined location (PUL) is diagnosed when there is a positive pregnancy test but no clear signs of an intrauterine or ectopic pregnancy on ultrasound. Further monitoring with serial beta-hCG levels and follow-up ultrasounds are necessary to determine the pregnancy’s location and viability.
  • ➤ pregnancy of undetermined location (PUL)
  • ➤ beta-hCG levels

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the gynecology OPD with an ultrasound report confirming an unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. She has no symptoms and is hemodynamically stable. Her β-hCG level is 600 IU/L. The scan shows a gestational sac measuring 20 mm in the right adnexa with no yolk sac or embryo seen. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Expectant management

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with an unruptured, asymptomatic ectopic pregnancy and low β-hCG levels (<1,000 IU/L) , expectant management is an appropriate option. Regular follow-up with serial β-hCG measurements is necessary to confirm that the pregnancy is resolving spontaneously.
  • ➤ β-hCG levels (<1,000 IU/L)
  • ➤ expectant management
  • ➤ β-hCG

questions.text: Of mullerian defects, which has the lowest associated risk of recurrent miscarriage and is shown here in this three-dimensional sonographic image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arcuate uterus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An arcuate uterus is a mild form of Müllerian anomaly associated with the lowest risk of recurrent miscarriage compared to other uterine anomalies. It generally allows for successful pregnancies with minimal complications.
  • ➤ arcuate uterus
  • ➤ lowest risk of recurrent miscarriage

questions.text: Characteristics of the soft, fleshy intrauterine growth, shown here exhibiting a single feeder vessel, include which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: The main diagnostic tool is a Pap smear

options.label: B
options.text: It is a rare cause of abnormal uterine bleeding

options.label: D
options.text: Use of combined oral contraceptive pills appears to be protective

questions.correct_answer: D. Use of combined oral contraceptive pills appears to be protective
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Use of combined oral contraceptive pills appears to be protective

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endometrial polyps are common causes of abnormal uterine bleeding and are associated with infertility in some cases. They can be diagnosed via ultrasound with Doppler imaging , and the use of combined oral contraceptives appears to reduce the risk of their development.
  • ➤ Endometrial polyps
  • ➤ ultrasound with Doppler imaging
  • ➤ combined oral contraceptives

questions.text: All can be used as distension media during diagnostic hysteroscopy except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Air

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Air should not be used as a distension medium in hysteroscopy due to the risk of air embolism . Safe alternatives include glycine , normal saline , and carbon dioxide , which provide effective uterine distension with minimal risks.
  • ➤ Air
  • ➤ air embolism
  • ➤ glycine
  • ➤ normal saline
  • ➤ carbon dioxide

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with a history of 2 previous abortions presents with secondary infertility. On evaluation, this finding was seen on hysteroscopy. What is the next management option?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hysteroscopic Adhesiolysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of intrauterine adhesions (Asherman’s syndrome) contributing to secondary infertility, hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the recommended treatment to restore uterine anatomy and improve fertility outcomes.
  • ➤ intrauterine adhesions (Asherman’s syndrome)
  • ➤ hysteroscopic adhesiolysis

questions.text: A 28-year-old G1P1 woman complains of significant dysmenorrhea & dyspareunia. She has regular periods & has no past history of any abdominal surgery or any vaginal infection. Which of the following tests would most likely identify the etiology of the infertility in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Laparoscopy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laparoscopy is the most appropriate test to identify the etiology of infertility in a patient with symptoms suggestive of endometriosis . It allows for direct visualization and diagnosis of endometrial implants, adhesions, and other pelvic abnormalities that can cause infertility and pelvic pain.
  • ➤ Laparoscopy
  • ➤ endometriosis

questions.text: A 32-year-old lady presents to the OPD. She had a Copper T inserted 5 years earlier and now wants to conceive. She has come for removal of the Copper T. Which instruments are required for this procedure? Cuscos speculum Vulsellum Uterine sound Artery forceps Anterior vaginal wall retractor Allis forceps
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) a, d

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For the removal of a Copper T , the essential instruments are Cusco's speculum for visualization and artery forceps to grasp and remove the IUD. Additional instruments are only needed if complications arise.
  • ➤ removal of a Copper T
  • ➤ Cusco's speculum
  • ➤ artery forceps

questions.text: In which surgery would the instrument shown below be used?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tubal ligation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The tubal forceps shown in the image is primarily used in tubal ligation procedures, where the fallopian tubes are manipulated for occlusion as a form of permanent contraception.
  • ➤ tubal forceps
  • ➤ tubal ligation

questions.text: Identify the procedure being done in the image:

options.label: D
options.text: Large loop excision of the transformation zone (LEEP)

questions.correct_answer: D. Large loop excision of the transformation zone (LEEP)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Large loop excision of the transformation zone (LEEP)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Large Loop Excision of the Transformation Zone (LEEP) is a procedure used to remove abnormal cervical tissue, typically in cases of cervical dysplasia or CIN. It serves both as a treatment and diagnostic tool.
  • ➤ Large Loop Excision of the Transformation Zone (LEEP)

questions.text: All are true regarding post evacuation surveillance of a Hydatiform mole except?

options.label: A
options.text: Incidence of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is higher following a partial mole.

options.label: B
options.text: Serial measurement of β hCG is done to detect persistent trophoblastic proliferation.

options.label: C
options.text: Initial baseline serum βhCG measurement is taken 48h post evacuation

options.label: D
options.text: β-hCG is done weekly till negative then monthly till 6 months

questions.correct_answer: A. Incidence of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is higher following a partial mole.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the post-evacuation surveillance of a hydatidiform mole , complete moles have a higher risk of progressing to gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) compared to partial moles. Serial β-hCG monitoring is essential to detect persistent disease, and the initial baseline measurement is taken 48 hours post-evacuation, with follow-up weekly and then monthly once levels normalize.
  • ➤ hydatidiform mole
  • ➤ gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN)
  • ➤ Serial β-hCG

questions.text: Karyotype of a complete mole is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A complete mole usually has a 46XX karyotype, resulting from the fertilization of an empty egg by a sperm that then duplicates, leading to abnormal trophoblastic growth and no fetal development.
  • ➤ complete mole
  • ➤ 46XX

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida is in labor in the 2nd stage. The resident asks the nurse to keep everything ready for the active management of the 3rd stage of labor. What drug should the nurse have ready?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Injection Oxytocin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The active management of the 3rd stage of labor involves the administration of oxytocin to promote uterine contractions and prevent postpartum hemorrhage. It is the first-line drug for this purpose, ensuring safe delivery and reducing the risk of excessive bleeding.
  • ➤ active management of the 3rd stage of labor
  • ➤ oxytocin

questions.text: While assisting a cesarean section for placenta previa, the patient starts bleeding. The gynecologist applies the following suture on the uterus and asks the name of it. What is this suture called?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) B-Lynch suture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The B-Lynch suture is a commonly used uterine compression suture to control postpartum hemorrhage, particularly in cases of uterine atony or placenta previa. It works by compressing the uterus and helping to stop bleeding, often used during cesarean sections.
  • ➤ B-Lynch suture
  • ➤ uterine compression suture

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statements regarding management of PPH:

options.label: A
options.text: Uterine massage is first step in management.

options.label: B
options.text: Oxytocin is given to all patients.

options.label: D
options.text: B-lynch suture is put if medical management fails

questions.correct_answer: C. Suction and evacuation is done
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the management of postpartum hemorrhage, the first steps include uterine massage and the administration of oxytocin . If these measures fail, additional uterotonics or surgical interventions such as the B-Lynch suture may be required. Suction and evacuation is not typically part of the routine management of PPH, unless there is suspicion of retained products of conception.
  • ➤ uterine massage
  • ➤ oxytocin
  • ➤ B-Lynch suture
  • ➤ Suction and evacuation

questions.text: Which of the following is a not a component of AMTSL?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Early cord clamping

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) includes uterotonic administration , uterine massage , and the Modified Brandt Andrews technique . Early cord clamping is not part of AMTSL, as delayed cord clamping is preferred for better neonatal outcomes.
  • ➤ Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL)
  • ➤ uterotonic administration
  • ➤ uterine massage
  • ➤ Modified Brandt Andrews technique
  • ➤ Early cord clamping

questions.text: A couple presents in the 1st trimester and ask about Down syndrome screening. They are very concerned as a relative in the family has Down syndrome. What is the ideal time for doing a Quadruple test?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 15-18 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Quadruple test is ideally performed between 15 and 18 weeks of gestation to screen for Down syndrome and other chromosomal abnormalities. First-trimester screening options are available earlier but involve different methods.
  • ➤ Quadruple test
  • ➤ 15 and 18 weeks
  • ➤ Down syndrome

questions.text: A pregnant woman (G3P2L0) presented at 9 weeks gestation. She has a history of conization 1 year ago for CIN3 and is currently on follow-up with no recurrence on PAP smear. She also has a history of preterm births at 30 and 32 weeks during her last 2 pregnancies. What is your next step in the management of this patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. Cervical length measurement on ultrasound
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cervical length measurement on ultrasound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a pregnant woman with a history of cervical conization and preterm births , the next step in management is to measure the cervical length via transvaginal ultrasound . If the cervix is shortened, interventions like cervical cerclage may be considered to prevent preterm birth.
  • ➤ cervical conization
  • ➤ preterm births
  • ➤ cervical length via transvaginal ultrasound
  • ➤ cervical cerclage

questions.text: A 29-year-old G2 presents at 33 weeks in preterm labor. Which of the following tocolytics is contraindicated?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Indomethacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Indomethacin is contraindicated as a tocolytic after 32 weeks of gestation due to the risk of premature closure of the ductus arteriosus and oligohydramnios . Other tocolytics, such as Atosiban and Magnesium sulfate , are safer options in later stages of pregnancy.
  • ➤ Indomethacin
  • ➤ 32 weeks of gestation
  • ➤ premature closure of the ductus arteriosus
  • ➤ oligohydramnios
  • ➤ Atosiban
  • ➤ Magnesium sulfate

questions.text: A 21-year-old G2P1 with a history of a prior preterm delivery presents at 32 weeks with abdominal pain. How will you confirm she is in preterm labor?
questions.correct_answer: D. Vaginal examination for cervical dilatation
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vaginal examination for cervical dilatation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The confirmation of preterm labor is based on the presence of cervical dilatation and effacement assessed via vaginal examination , combined with regular uterine contractions. Other methods, like cervical length measurement and fetal fibronectin, assess risk but do not confirm labor.
  • ➤ confirmation of preterm labor
  • ➤ cervical dilatation and effacement
  • ➤ vaginal examination

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother due to concerns that her daughter has not had her menses. She is healthy, has no developmental delay, and is not sexually active. Her maternal aunt has primary infertility, and her maternal grandmother had ovarian cancer. Physical examination shows Tanner stage 5 breast development but scanty axillary and pubic hair. The pelvic exam reveals normal external genitalia but a blind vaginal pouch. Ultrasound shows an absent uterus and ovaries. What is the likely karyotype?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 46 XY

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) is characterized by a 46XY karyotype, normal female external genitalia, absent uterus and ovaries, normal breast development, and sparse or absent pubic and axillary hair due to androgen insensitivity.
  • ➤ Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS)
  • ➤ 46XY

questions.text: A 28-year-old nulligravida presents with primary amenorrhea. She is diagnosed with 46XY gonadal dysgenesis. During pelvic laparoscopy, what is the expected finding?

options.label: A
options.text: Streak gonads and male internal genitalia

options.label: B
options.text: Streak gonads and female internal genitalia

options.label: C
options.text: Empty pelvis (no gonads or internal genitalia)

options.label: D
options.text: Bilateral abdominal testes and male internal genitalia

questions.correct_answer: B. Streak gonads and female internal genitalia
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Streak gonads and female internal genitalia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In 46XY gonadal dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome) , the expected findings on laparoscopy are streak gonads and female internal genitalia . This condition occurs due to the failure of gonadal development and the absence of sufficient testosterone and Müllerian-inhibiting factor (AMH), resulting in a female phenotype despite the 46XY karyotype.
  • ➤ 46XY gonadal dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome)
  • ➤ streak gonads
  • ➤ female internal genitalia

questions.text: A 18-year-old girl presents to OPD with primary amenorrhea, normal breast and pubic & axillary hair development. On examination, vagina is absent and there is inguinal hernia. Serum estradiol and FSH level are normal. Ultrasound shows absent uterus and vagina. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) MRKH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome is characterized by the congenital absence of the uterus and upper vagina in individuals with a 46XX karyotype , while maintaining normal ovarian function, which leads to typical female secondary sexual characteristics. It is an important cause of primary amenorrhea in women with normal breast and pubic/axillary hair development.
  • ➤ Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome
  • ➤ 46XX karyotype
  • ➤ primary amenorrhea

questions.text: A 25-year-old G3P2 presented to the OPD at 29 weeks. Her blood group is B negative and her husband's blood group is B positive. An ICT (indirect Coombs test) revealed high titers of 1 in 32, and an MCA (Middle Cerebral Artery) Doppler shows an increased peak systolic velocity (>1.5 MoM). Which of the following is correct?

options.label: B
options.text: Arrange for cordocentesis and consider Intra uterine transfusion if PCV < 30%

options.label: C
options.text: Give Betamethasone for fetal lung maturity and deliver

questions.correct_answer: B. Arrange for cordocentesis and consider Intra uterine transfusion if PCV < 30%
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arrange for cordocentesis and consider Intra uterine transfusion if PCV < 30%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of Rh alloimmunization with elevated MCA peak systolic velocity (>1.5 MoM), the next step is cordocentesis to confirm fetal anemia. If fetal hemoglobin levels are low (PCV <30%), intrauterine transfusion is indicated to treat the anemia and improve fetal outcomes.
  • ➤ Rh alloimmunization
  • ➤ MCA peak systolic velocity
  • ➤ cordocentesis
  • ➤ intrauterine transfusion

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the OPD for evaluation of absent periods. The patient had a vaginal delivery 8 months ago, and her postpartum course was complicated by secondary PPH requiring blood transfusion and D&E for retained products. She was started on combined OCPs 2 months ago but has not had vaginal bleeding. She had regular monthly cycles before this pregnancy. She is not lactating and is bottle-feeding her baby. There is no headache, galactorrhea, or hot flushes. Her BMI is 31, vitals are normal, and the pelvic exam shows a clear vaginal discharge with a well-rugated vagina. The uterus is small and anteverted. UPT is negative, and FSH and TSH are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Asherman syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Asherman syndrome should be suspected in patients with a history of uterine surgery (e.g., D&E for retained products) who present with secondary amenorrhea and normal hormone levels (e.g., FSH, TSH). It is caused by intrauterine adhesions that prevent normal endometrial shedding and menstrual bleeding.
  • ➤ Asherman syndrome
  • ➤ amenorrhea

questions.text: A newborn was noted to have the following lesion on the scalp. Which drug taken in pregnancy could have caused this?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methimazole use during the first trimester of pregnancy is associated with aplasia cutis congenita , a congenital absence of skin, typically on the scalp. This teratogenic effect makes propylthiouracil the preferred treatment for hyperthyroidism during the first trimester.
  • ➤ Methimazole
  • ➤ aplasia cutis congenita

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen on examination of a fetus in transverse lie?

options.label: C
options.text: Lower pole empty on pelvic grip

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Fetal heart in flank

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of transverse lie, the key examination findings include a gridiron feel across the abdomen, an empty lower uterine pole, and often uterine height less than the period of gestation (POG). The fetal heart is typically not auscultated in the flank, but rather in more central locations depending on the exact positioning.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents at 37 weeks in early labor. After a few hours, the patient complains of leaking per vaginum. The CTG shows a prolonged deceleration, and on vaginal examination, the cord is felt in the vagina. The cervix is 8 cm dilated. What is the next best step?
questions.correct_answer: B. Lift the presenting part up
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of umbilical cord prolapse with fetal distress, the immediate priority is to lift the presenting part to relieve pressure on the cord and maintain blood flow. The patient should then be prepared for emergency cesarean section to expedite delivery and prevent fetal hypoxia.
  • ➤ umbilical cord prolapse
  • ➤ lift the presenting part
  • ➤ emergency cesarean section

questions.text: The incidence of cord prolapse is highest in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The highest risk of cord prolapse occurs in footling breech presentation , as the feet do not adequately fill the pelvic inlet, leaving space for the cord to descend and prolapse. Prompt recognition and management are critical in such cases to prevent fetal distress.
  • ➤ cord prolapse
  • ➤ footling breech presentation

questions.text: Which is not a component of the Modified Bishop score?
questions.correct_answer: D. Position of the fetal head
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Modified Bishop score is used to assess the cervix's readiness for labor and includes parameters like cervical dilatation, effacement, consistency, position , and fetal station . The position of the fetal head is not included in this scoring system.
  • ➤ Modified Bishop score
  • ➤ cervical dilatation, effacement, consistency, position
  • ➤ fetal station
  • ➤ position of the fetal head
  • ➤ not

questions.text: A patient presents in labor at term. Clinical pelvimetry is performed. She has an oval-shaped pelvis with the antero-posterior diameter at the inlet more than the transverse diameter. On abdominal examination, there is sub-umbilical flattening and the fetal hears is auscultated on the flanks. The most likely kind of pelvis is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An anthropoid pelvis is characterized by an oval-shaped inlet with a longer anteroposterior diameter than the transverse diameter. It is associated with fetal positions such as occiput posterior or transverse, which may lead to the fetal heart being auscultated on the flanks and sub-umbilical flattening.
  • ➤ anthropoid pelvis
  • ➤ oval-shaped inlet

questions.text: If the lower most portion of presenting fetal part at ischial spine, it means the station is at?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 0

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When the lowermost portion of the presenting fetal part is at the level of the ischial spines , the station is considered to be 0 . Negative stations indicate that the presenting part is higher in the pelvis, while positive stations indicate that it is descending toward delivery.
  • ➤ ischial spines
  • ➤ 0

questions.text: If the fetus enters the pelvis with its sagittal suture in the transverse diameter of the pelvis, internal rotation will happen by how many degrees?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 90 degrees

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When the fetal head enters the pelvis in a transverse position , it usually rotates 90 degrees during labor to align the occiput with the anteroposterior diameter of the pelvis, facilitating delivery.
  • ➤ transverse position
  • ➤ 90 degrees

questions.text: Grade 2 moulding means?

options.label: D
options.text: Scalp edema with irreducible overlap of suture lines

questions.correct_answer: B. Reducible overlap of suture lines
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Grade 2 moulding involves a reducible overlap of the suture lines , allowing the fetal skull bones to shift and accommodate the birth canal. This is part of the normal adaptation during labor but should be monitored closely to prevent complications.
  • ➤ Grade 2 moulding
  • ➤ reducible overlap of the suture lines

questions.text: A midwife at a PHC is monitoring pregnancy and maintaining the partograph of the progression of labor of a 22-year-old primigravida. At how much cervical dilation should the WHO modified partograph plotting be started?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The WHO modified partograph should be started when the cervix is dilated to 4 cm or more, marking the beginning of the active phase of labor , to monitor the progression of labor and manage potential complications effectively.
  • ➤ WHO modified partograph
  • ➤ 4 cm
  • ➤ active phase of labor

questions.text: A 30y old G2 presents in active labor at 9 am. She is 6 cm dilated, well effaced with the Vertex at -1 station. A WHO modified partograph is plotted. At what time do you expect her to be fully dilated?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a multiparous woman in active labor, the cervix dilates at approximately 1 cm per hour . If she is 6 cm dilated at 9 am, she is expected to be fully dilated by 1 pm .
  • ➤ multiparous woman
  • ➤ 1 cm per hour
  • ➤ 6 cm
  • ➤ 1 pm

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the WHO Labor care guide?

options.label: A
options.text: There is no monitoring of the 2nd stage of labor

options.label: C
options.text: Labor companionship, pain relief posture and fluid intake are all important components.

options.label: D
options.text: It follows evidence based time limits at each cm of cervical dilatation

questions.correct_answer: A. There is no monitoring of the 2nd stage of labor
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The WHO Labor Care Guide monitors both the first and second stages of labor and begins plotting labor progression after 5 cm cervical dilation . It includes important aspects like labor companionship , pain relief , and fluid intake , and follows evidence-based time limits to ensure proper labor management.
  • ➤ WHO Labor Care Guide
  • ➤ first
  • ➤ second stages of labor
  • ➤ 5 cm cervical dilation
  • ➤ labor companionship
  • ➤ pain relief
  • ➤ fluid intake
  • ➤ evidence-based time limits

questions.text: Following delivery of a 4kg baby to a mother with gestational diabetes, you note that there is a tear involving the perineum and external anal sphincter with intact mucosa. The grade of the tear is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A third-degree perineal tear involves the external anal sphincter (and sometimes the internal sphincter), but the rectal mucosa remains intact. It is important to recognize the degree of the tear to manage it appropriately and prevent complications such as fecal incontinence.
  • ➤ third-degree perineal tear
  • ➤ external anal sphincter

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2P1 woman at 39 weeks gestation presents with painful uterine contractions. She also complains of minimal vaginal blood mixed with some mucus. Which of the following describes the most likely etiology of her bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bloody show

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A bloody show occurs when the cervix effaces and dilates in preparation for labor, releasing the mucus plug mixed with small amounts of blood. This is a normal finding at the onset of labor and is different from the heavy or more concerning bleeding associated with conditions like placenta previa or placental abruption .
  • ➤ bloody show
  • ➤ mucus plug
  • ➤ placenta previa
  • ➤ placental abruption

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida woman presents at 29 weeks gestation with headache and a blood pressure of 160/110 mm Hg. Investigations reveal 2+ proteinuria on dipstick, an elevated SGOT and SGPT and a platelet count of 80,000/mm3? What is the best management?

options.label: C
options.text: Magnesium sulphate therapy and induction of labor

questions.correct_answer: C. Magnesium sulphate therapy and induction of labor
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Magnesium sulphate therapy and induction of labor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of severe preeclampsia or HELLP syndrome (elevated liver enzymes and low platelets), the best management includes magnesium sulfate to prevent seizures and immediate delivery to prevent further complications for both the mother and fetus. Early delivery is the only definitive treatment.
  • ➤ severe preeclampsia
  • ➤ HELLP syndrome
  • ➤ magnesium sulfate
  • ➤ immediate delivery

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida is worried about her risk of developing preeclampsia. What intervention would help reduce the risk in her?

options.label: B
options.text: Calcium supplementation started prior to 12 weeks

options.label: C
options.text: Aspirin 150 mg/ day prior to 16 weeks

options.label: D
options.text: Antioxidants – ascorbic acid and α-tocopherol prior to 12 weeks

questions.correct_answer: C. Aspirin 150 mg/ day prior to 16 weeks
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For women at high risk of developing preeclampsia , starting low-dose aspirin (75–150 mg/day) before 16 weeks gestation is the most evidence-based intervention to reduce the risk of developing preeclampsia.
  • ➤ preeclampsia
  • ➤ low-dose aspirin (75–150 mg/day) before 16 weeks gestation

questions.text: All the following precautions are taken in labor in a woman with pre-eclampsia except?

options.label: A
options.text: Cut short the 2nd stage of labor

options.label: B
options.text: Prophylactic methylergometrine at the delivery of anterior shoulder

questions.correct_answer: B. Prophylactic methylergometrine at the delivery of anterior shoulder
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In labor management of women with pre-eclampsia , the use of methylergometrine should be avoided due to its potential to cause severe hypertension. Safer alternatives like oxytocin should be used to prevent postpartum hemorrhage.
  • ➤ pre-eclampsia
  • ➤ methylergometrine
  • ➤ oxytocin

questions.text: A multiparous patient who did not attend any antenatal visit and came to the emergency room with a complaint of bleeding. On examination, uterine tone was increased with BP >144/92 mmHg. Which of the following tests supports the diagnosis of preeclampsia?

options.label: D
options.text: Total protein of 252mg in a 24 hour urine collection

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Creatinine 1.24 mg/dl

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Serum creatinine >1.1 mg/dL is an indicator of renal involvement in preeclampsia and supports the diagnosis in patients with elevated blood pressure after 20 weeks of gestation. Other indicators, such as thrombocytopenia or proteinuria, may indicate severity but are not always present early in the disease course.
  • ➤ Serum creatinine >1.1 mg/dL

questions.text: A 36-year-old primigravida presents with seizures to the emergency. On examination, she is 36 weeks pregnant with BP 150/100 mmHg. She is given a loading dose of magnesium sulfate (MgSO₄) as per the Pritchard regime but has another seizure. Which of the following should be done next?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Additional magnesium sulphate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of eclampsia with recurrent seizures, the next best step is to administer an additional dose of magnesium sulfate before considering other anticonvulsant options. Magnesium sulfate is the first-line therapy for eclampsia, and adequate dosing should be ensured.
  • ➤ eclampsia
  • ➤ additional dose of magnesium sulfate

questions.text: Which of the following are features of magnesium toxicity in pregnancy: Loss of deep tendon reflex Decreased respiratory rate Decreased urine output Hypertension Increased heart rate
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) a, b

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Magnesium toxicity in pregnancy is primarily characterized by loss of deep tendon reflexes and decreased respiratory rate . It is crucial to monitor patients receiving magnesium sulfate for these signs to prevent severe complications like respiratory arrest.
  • ➤ Magnesium toxicity
  • ➤ loss of deep tendon reflexes
  • ➤ decreased respiratory rate

questions.text: Which of the following infections can cause fetal hydrops?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parvovirus B19 infection is a well-known cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis , characterized by severe fetal anemia and heart failure. Other infections, like rubella , varicella , and malaria , can cause significant fetal complications but are not typically associated with fetal hydrops.
  • ➤ Parvovirus B19 infection
  • ➤ non-immune hydrops fetalis
  • ➤ rubella
  • ➤ varicella
  • ➤ malaria

questions.text: A 26-year-old test positive for VDRL on routine antenatal investigations. She is 8 weeks pregnant. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Benzathene penicillin 2.4 million units IM single dose

options.label: C
options.text: Send fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS)

questions.correct_answer: C. Send fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Send fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A positive VDRL test during pregnancy requires confirmation with a treponemal test such as FTA-ABS to definitively diagnose syphilis. If confirmed, benzathine penicillin is the treatment of choice to prevent maternal and fetal complications.
  • ➤ VDRL
  • ➤ treponemal test
  • ➤ FTA-ABS
  • ➤ benzathine penicillin

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2P1L1 teacher presents at 38 weeks with fever and rash for 2 days. She gives a history of contact with a child in her class who had chickenpox 10 days earlier. What is the next best step in management?
questions.correct_answer: B. Oral Acyclovir, antipyretics, and hydration
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In pregnant women with active varicella infection , oral acyclovir , along with supportive care such as antipyretics and hydration , is the most appropriate management. Immediate delivery is not necessary unless there are severe complications, and VZIG is only used for post-exposure prophylaxis before symptoms develop.
  • ➤ active varicella infection
  • ➤ oral acyclovir
  • ➤ antipyretics
  • ➤ hydration

questions.text: A 27-year G2P1L1 presents at 33 weeks with itching mainly on the palms of her hands. The itching worsens at night. She gives a similar history in her 1 st pregnancy. On examination, her BP is 130/84 mmHg. There is mild icterus and abdominal examination reveals a 32 weeks uterus with fetal heart rate of 140 bpm. Her SGOT is 112 IU/L, SGPT is 124 IU/L and serum bilirubin is 2 mg%. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Monitor BP and plan delivery at 37 weeks

options.label: D
options.text: Weekly LFT and plan delivery at 38 weeks

questions.correct_answer: D. Weekly LFT and plan delivery at 38 weeks
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Weekly LFT and plan delivery at 38 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP), patients with mild to moderate symptoms may be managed with weekly liver function tests (LFTs) and close fetal monitoring, with planned delivery around 38 weeks. This approach minimizes risks associated with both ICP and preterm birth.

questions.text: A 21-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks presents with jaundice for 3 days. On examination, BP is 140/90 mmHg. Serum bilirubin is 4 mg%, fibrinogen is 50 mg/dl, hemoglobin is 8 g%, platelet count is 90,000/mm³, RBS is 40 mg/dl, AST is 85, and ALT is 80. Peripheral smear shows normocytic normochromic anemia. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: B. Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy (AFLP)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy (AFLP) is a serious condition characterized by jaundice , hypoglycemia , coagulopathy , thrombocytopenia , and liver dysfunction in the third trimester. Early recognition and prompt management are crucial to prevent maternal and fetal complications.
  • ➤ Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy (AFLP)
  • ➤ jaundice
  • ➤ hypoglycemia
  • ➤ coagulopathy
  • ➤ thrombocytopenia
  • ➤ liver dysfunction

questions.text: Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat strategy to reduce the prevalence of anemia, the color of the iron and folic acid tablets given to the adolescent age group are:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Blue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the Anemia Mukt Bharat strategy, blue tablets containing 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid are provided to adolescents (10-19 years) to address the issue of anemia in this vulnerable group.
  • ➤ Anemia Mukt Bharat
  • ➤ blue tablets
  • ➤ 60 mg of elemental iron
  • ➤ 500 mcg of folic acid

questions.text: A 20-year-old G1 is on treatment for iron deficiency anemia with oral iron, which was started at 24 weeks. She visits the antenatal OPD after 1 week. What is the earliest lab evidence of response to therapy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Reticulocytosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The earliest laboratory indicator of response to oral iron therapy in the treatment of iron deficiency anemia is reticulocytosis , which occurs within 5-7 days of initiating therapy.
  • ➤ earliest laboratory indicator
  • ➤ reticulocytosis
  • ➤ 5-7 days

questions.text: A couple went for pre-conceptional counseling and was detected to be anemic. On investigation, they were both found to have beta thalassemia minor. The chance their fetus will have thalassemia major is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 25%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When both parents have beta-thalassemia minor , the chance of their child inheriting thalassemia major is 25% , as the condition follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.
  • ➤ beta-thalassemia minor
  • ➤ thalassemia major
  • ➤ 25%

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida with a known history of epilepsy on sodium valproate presents to the antenatal OPD at 6 weeks. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the management of epilepsy in pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: Folic acid 5 mg to be started pre-conceptionally and continued throughout pregnancy

options.label: B
options.text: Single anti-epileptic drug at the least dose is preferred during pregnancy

options.label: D
options.text: There is an increased risk of developing childhood epilepsy in the fetus

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sodium valproate is safe

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sodium valproate should be avoided in pregnancy due to its association with major congenital malformations and neurodevelopmental disorders . Alternative anti-epileptic drugs, such as lamotrigine or levetiracetam , are preferred. Women with epilepsy should receive 5 mg of folic acid pre-conceptionally and throughout pregnancy to reduce the risk of neural tube defects.
  • ➤ Sodium valproate
  • ➤ major congenital malformations
  • ➤ neurodevelopmental disorders
  • ➤ lamotrigine
  • ➤ levetiracetam
  • ➤ 5 mg of folic acid

questions.text: A 36-year-old primigravida underwent a targeted imaging for fetal anomalies. On 3-D ultrasound, the following anomaly was noted. What teratogenic drug could have caused this anomaly?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sodium valproate is a known teratogen associated with cleft lip/palate , neural tube defects , and other congenital anomalies. It should be avoided in pregnancy if possible, and alternative anti-epileptic drugs with lower teratogenic risk should be used.
  • ➤ Sodium valproate
  • ➤ cleft lip/palate
  • ➤ neural tube defects

questions.text: When the fetal head is at the perineum and the skull has reached the pelvic floor, which of the following is true?

options.label: D
options.text: May lead to deep transverse arrest

questions.correct_answer: A. Outlet Forceps can be applied
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Outlet Forceps can be applied

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Outlet forceps can be applied when the fetal head is at the perineum, and this is a safe and common technique in certain situations where assistance in completing the delivery is needed.
  • ➤ Outlet forceps

questions.text: In the POP-Q system of uterine prolapse, how many fixed points are there?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The POP-Q system uses 6 fixed points to assess and quantify pelvic organ prolapse. It provides a standardized, objective approach to describing the severity and extent of prolapse.
  • ➤ POP-Q system
  • ➤ 6 fixed points

questions.text: An 89-year-old lady with multiple medical co-morbidities presents with pelvic organ prolapse. She has a grade IV prolapse. Which of the following surgical options would be most appropriate for her?

options.label: A
options.text: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Colpocleisis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For an elderly woman with multiple medical co-morbidities and grade IV pelvic organ prolapse , colpocleisis is the preferred surgical option due to its minimally invasive nature and the lower risk associated with it. This procedure is ideal for patients who are no longer sexually active and wish to avoid more extensive surgery.
  • ➤ multiple medical co-morbidities
  • ➤ grade IV pelvic organ prolapse
  • ➤ colpocleisis

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman complains of constipation and difficulty having bowel movements. She states that she often needs to use her fingers to push her vagina backward to achieve a bowel movement. Her history is otherwise unremarkable. On examination, the lower part of the posterior vaginal wall is seen to prolapse out. The cervix or the bladder does not descend down on bearing. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Posterior colporrhaphy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with rectocele (posterior vaginal wall prolapse), the appropriate treatment is posterior colporrhaphy . This procedure helps repair the rectocele and restores normal vaginal and rectal anatomy, thereby improving symptoms like difficulty with bowel movements.
  • ➤ rectocele
  • ➤ posterior colporrhaphy

questions.text: A lady underwent vaginal hysterectomy for Carcinoma cervix. Following the surgery after her urethral catheter was removed, she complained of leaking of urine. Methylene blue dye was instilled in her bladder through her urethra, and she was given oral Phenazopyridine dye. After some time, her pads were checked and it showed yellow staining at the top most pad, while the middle or bottom pads were unstained. She is likely to have?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of yellow-stained pads after administration of phenazopyridine and the absence of blue staining from the methylene blue test indicates a ureterovaginal fistula , where urine is leaking from the ureter directly into the vagina, bypassing the bladder.
  • ➤ yellow-stained pads
  • ➤ phenazopyridine
  • ➤ ureterovaginal fistula

questions.text: A -55- years old multigravida with history of frequently micturating due to coughing laughing & sneezing. The diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Stress incontinence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stress incontinence is the involuntary leakage of urine during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing , laughing , and sneezing . It is commonly seen in women, especially those with a history of multiple pregnancies or weakened pelvic floor muscles.
  • ➤ Stress incontinence
  • ➤ coughing
  • ➤ laughing
  • ➤ sneezing

questions.text: At what stage of the female life is the highest number of oocytes found in the ovary?
questions.correct_answer: D. In utero at 5 month's gestation
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The highest number of oocytes in the female ovary is found in utero at around 5 months of gestation , where approximately 6-7 million oocytes are present. This number declines progressively through life due to atresia.
  • ➤ in utero at around 5 months of gestation
  • ➤ 6-7 million

questions.text: The correct order of lochia during the puerperium is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rubra, serosa, alba

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct order of lochia during the puerperium is rubra (first stage with red blood), serosa (second stage with pinkish-brown discharge), and finally alba (third stage with whitish or yellowish discharge).
  • ➤ lochia
  • ➤ rubra
  • ➤ serosa
  • ➤ alba

questions.text: A patient who delivered few hours back collapses and dies. During autopsy, alveolar fluid analysis shows presence of hair and squamous epithelial cells. Most likely cause of death?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Amniotic fluid embolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) is a rare but serious obstetric complication where amniotic fluid or fetal debris enters the maternal circulation, leading to cardiovascular collapse, respiratory failure, and often disseminated intravascular coagulation. The presence of fetal cells (hair and squamous epithelial cells) in the alveolar fluid is diagnostic of AFE.
  • ➤ Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE)
  • ➤ fetal cells (hair and squamous epithelial cells)

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman has just delivered her second baby. She asks the resident for a contraceptive method. The resident suggests an intra-uterine copper-containing device. How soon after delivery can this be inserted?
questions.correct_answer: A. Within 10 mins of placental delivery
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Within 10 mins of placental delivery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A copper-containing IUD can be safely inserted within 10 minutes of placental delivery, providing effective long-term contraception immediately after childbirth. If not inserted within 48 hours, it is advisable to wait until 4-6 weeks postpartum to minimize the risk of expulsion.
  • ➤ copper-containing IUD
  • ➤ within 10 minutes
  • ➤ 4-6 weeks postpartum

questions.text: The 4th trimester of pregnancy refers to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The 4th trimester refers to the first 12 weeks following delivery, a critical period for maternal recovery, infant care, and support for physical and mental health.
  • ➤ 4th trimester
  • ➤ first 12 weeks

questions.text: A 36-year-old lady with a multiple pregnancy conceived through IVF presents at 32 weeks with painless vaginal bleeding. This is the 2nd such episode, and ultrasound reveals placenta previa. Her pulse rate is 80/min, BP is 110/70 mmHg, FHR 1 is 140 bpm, and FHR 2 is 156 bpm. How will you manage this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Arrange blood and plan cesarean at 34 weeks

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Expectant management

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of placenta previa with stable maternal and fetal conditions at 32 weeks, expectant management is the best approach to allow for further fetal maturation. Close monitoring, corticosteroid administration, and planning for delivery at 34-36 weeks (or earlier if complications arise) is the appropriate course of action.
  • ➤ placenta previa
  • ➤ expectant management
  • ➤ 34-36 weeks

questions.text: All are true regarding morbidly adherent placenta except:

options.label: A
options.text: There is absence of the decidua basalis and Nitabuch layer

options.label: B
options.text: MRI is useful in diagnosing accreta in posterior placentas

options.label: C
options.text: During cesarean a gentle attempt is made at delivering the placenta and abandoned if there is no separation

options.label: D
options.text: Upper segment cesarean is usually performed to deliver the baby

questions.correct_answer: C. During cesarean a gentle attempt is made at delivering the placenta and abandoned if there is no separation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) During cesarean a gentle attempt is made at delivering the placenta and abandoned if there is no separation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients with morbidly adherent placenta , it is crucial not to attempt manual removal of the placenta during cesarean delivery. Instead, the placenta is often left in situ, and further interventions like hysterectomy are planned to prevent life-threatening hemorrhage.
  • ➤ morbidly adherent placenta
  • ➤ not to attempt manual removal
  • ➤ hysterectomy

questions.text: The following type of abnormal placenta is most often associated with placenta previa:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Succenturiate placenta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Succenturiate placenta is a placental abnormality where one or more accessory lobes develop, and it is most often associated with placenta previa , increasing the risk of the placenta covering the cervical os.
  • ➤ Succenturiate placenta
  • ➤ placenta previa

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida with preeclampsia and fetal distress underwent an emergency LSCS (lower segment cesarean section). Following delivery of the baby, the uterus appeared as shown in the image. What could have been the reason for fetal distress?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Abruptio Placenta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Placental abruption can lead to a Couvelaire uterus , characterized by blood infiltration into the uterine muscle. It is a cause of fetal distress due to compromised placental function, and it requires immediate intervention, often through cesarean delivery.
  • ➤ Placental abruption
  • ➤ Couvelaire uterus
  • ➤ fetal distress

questions.text: A 21-year-old primigravida at 36 weeks with chronic hypertension presents with vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain. On examination, her BP is 140/100, the uterus is tense and contracting, and the fetal heart rate is not auscultated. PV examination reveals the cervix is 5 cm dilated and well effaced. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected placental abruption with fetal demise and a dilated cervix , ARM and oxytocin augmentation are the preferred management steps to expedite vaginal delivery and minimize risks to the mother. Cesarean section is not necessary if vaginal delivery is feasible.
  • ➤ placental abruption
  • ➤ fetal demise
  • ➤ dilated cervix
  • ➤ ARM
  • ➤ oxytocin augmentation

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman with a history of hypertension presents to the antenatal clinic for a routine check-up. She is currently 24 weeks pregnant, and her blood pressure is well controlled on a combination of methyldopa and labetalol. She is concerned about the potential risks of these medications to her unborn baby. Which of the following statements about the use of methyldopa and labetalol in pregnancy is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Methyldopa and labetalol are contraindicated in pregnancy due to their teratogenic effects.

options.label: B
options.text: Methyldopa and labetalol are safe choices for the management of hypertension during pregnancy

options.label: C
options.text: Methyldopa is safe, but labetalol should be avoided during pregnancy

options.label: D
options.text: Methyldopa and labetalol can cause intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) and should be used with caution.

questions.correct_answer: B. Methyldopa and labetalol are safe choices for the management of hypertension during pregnancy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Methyldopa and labetalol are safe choices for the management of hypertension during pregnancy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methyldopa and labetalol are among the preferred antihypertensive medications used during pregnancy due to their safety profiles and effectiveness in managing maternal blood pressure without posing significant risks to the fetus.
  • ➤ Methyldopa
  • ➤ labetalol
  • ➤ safety profiles

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida presents for induction of labor at 41 weeks. Her cervix is unfavorable with a Bishop score of 4. You proceed with cervical ripening using the agent shown below. This medication belongs to which group of drugs?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prostaglandins

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prostaglandins (such as misoprostol and dinoprostone ) are the drugs of choice for cervical ripening during labor induction, especially when the cervix is unfavorable.
  • ➤ Prostaglandins
  • ➤ misoprostol
  • ➤ dinoprostone
  • ➤ cervical ripening

questions.text: Which of the following is not a test of ovarian reserve?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Day 10 Antral Follicle Count

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To assess ovarian reserve , standard tests include the measurement of Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) , Day 2/3 FSH , and the Antral Follicle Count (AFC) done on Day 2 to Day 5 of the menstrual cycle. A Day 10 AFC is not part of the routine assessment of ovarian reserve.
  • ➤ ovarian reserve
  • ➤ Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH)
  • ➤ Day 2/3 FSH
  • ➤ Antral Follicle Count (AFC)
  • ➤ Day 2 to Day 5
  • ➤ Day 10 AFC

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is not contraindicated in Pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rabies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rabies vaccine is an inactivated vaccine and is safe to administer during pregnancy , especially in cases of potential exposure. Live attenuated vaccines like measles , rubella , and varicella are contraindicated during pregnancy due to the potential risk to the fetus.
  • ➤ Rabies vaccine
  • ➤ safe to administer during pregnancy
  • ➤ Live attenuated vaccines
  • ➤ measles
  • ➤ rubella
  • ➤ varicella

questions.text: What is the preferred schedule of immunization in pregnancy regarding tetanus as per the ministry of health and family welfare?

options.label: A
options.text: Inj Td: 1st dose: early in pregnancy, 2nd dose: After 4 weeks; booster: if received 2 Td doses in a pregnancy within the last 3 years

options.label: B
options.text: Inj TT 1st dose early in pregnancy, 2nd dose after 4 weeks and booster if received 2 TT doses in a pregnancy within the last 3 years

options.label: C
options.text: Inj Tdap 1st dose in the 2nd trimester and 2nd dose in the 3rd trimester

options.label: D
options.text: Inj TT or Td 1st dose in early pregnancy and 2nd dose after 4 weeks

questions.correct_answer: A. Inj Td: 1st dose: early in pregnancy, 2nd dose: After 4 weeks; booster: if received 2 Td doses in a pregnancy within the last 3 years
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The preferred schedule for tetanus immunization in pregnancy as per the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare is the Td vaccine , given in two doses— 1st dose early in pregnancy and 2nd dose after 4 weeks . A booster dose is given if the woman has had 2 Td doses in the previous 3 years.
  • ➤ Ministry of Health and Family Welfare
  • ➤ Td vaccine
  • ➤ 1st dose early in pregnancy
  • ➤ 2nd dose after 4 weeks
  • ➤ booster dose

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to OPD with complaint of discharge per vagina associated with intense itching. Wet mount of vaginal secretions is shown below. Which of the following is true:

options.label: C
options.text: Will be associated with curdy white discharge

options.label: D
options.text: Fluconazole is the treatment of choice

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Associated with strawberry cervix

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trichomonas vaginalis infection is characterized by frothy greenish-yellow vaginal discharge , intense itching , and can be associated with a strawberry cervix on examination. It is treated with metronidazole or tinidazole .
  • ➤ Trichomonas vaginalis
  • ➤ frothy greenish-yellow vaginal discharge
  • ➤ intense itching
  • ➤ strawberry cervix
  • ➤ metronidazole
  • ➤ tinidazole

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of itching in the vagina, vaginal discharge, and dyspareunia. What is the best treatment option?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vaginal estrogen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In postmenopausal women with symptoms of vaginal itching , discharge , and dyspareunia , vulvovaginal atrophy (atrophic vaginitis) is the most likely diagnosis, and vaginal estrogen is the best treatment option to relieve symptoms and restore vaginal health.
  • ➤ vaginal itching
  • ➤ discharge
  • ➤ dyspareunia
  • ➤ vulvovaginal atrophy
  • ➤ vaginal estrogen

questions.text: A 36-year-old P3L3, ligated woman presents to OPD with lower abdominal pain and discharge from vagina. On examination, there is uterine tenderness. What is the likely diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pelvic inflammatory disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is characterized by lower abdominal pain , vaginal discharge , and uterine tenderness . It is an infection of the upper reproductive tract, often caused by sexually transmitted pathogens, and requires prompt treatment to avoid complications.
  • ➤ Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
  • ➤ lower abdominal pain
  • ➤ vaginal discharge
  • ➤ uterine tenderness

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl with a long-standing history of irregular menstrual cycles and amenorrhea presents with an ultrasound picture shown below. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in her?

options.label: A
options.text: Male pattern hair growth on lower abdomen

options.label: B
options.text: Thickened dark skin on inner thighs

options.label: D
options.text: High serum levels of high-density lipoproteins

questions.correct_answer: D. High serum levels of high-density lipoproteins
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) High serum levels of high-density lipoproteins

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is characterized by irregular menstrual cycles, hyperandrogenism, and insulin resistance. It is typically associated with low HDL levels, which makes high HDL the least likely feature in patients with PCOS.
  • ➤ Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
  • ➤ low HDL
  • ➤ high HDL

questions.text: A 34y G2P1 presents at 35 weeks. She has no complaints and is appreciating fetal movements well. She had a previous classical cesarean at 25 weeks for eclampsia and severe FGR. She is currently on low dose aspirin and prenatal vitamins. On examination, the uterus SFH is 38 cm and FHR is 140 bpm. An ultrasound reveals a single live fetus in breech presentation, placenta posterior and amniotic fluid normal. The patient desires a vaginal delivery. What is the best management?

options.label: D
options.text: Await spontaneous labor and then do an internal podalic version

questions.correct_answer: B. Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients with a previous classical cesarean section and breech presentation, an elective cesarean at 37 weeks is recommended to avoid the risk of uterine rupture.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G2 woman with a previous lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) is in labor at 38 weeks. She suddenly experiences vaginal bleeding and loss of uterine contractions. The fetal heart rate (FHR) cannot be auscultated. What is the next best management option?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Emergency laparotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a pregnant woman with a previous LSCS who presents with sudden vaginal bleeding , loss of uterine contractions , and inability to auscultate the fetal heart rate, uterine rupture is the most likely diagnosis. Immediate emergency laparotomy is the appropriate management to save the mother's life and attempt to save the fetus if still viable.
  • ➤ LSCS
  • ➤ vaginal bleeding
  • ➤ loss of uterine contractions
  • ➤ uterine rupture
  • ➤ emergency laparotomy

questions.text: A woman presents to the antenatal OPD and is unsure of her dates. On abdominal examination, external ballottement is elicited. When is the earliest this sign can be seen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 18 – 20 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ External ballottement is a sign that can be detected starting from 18 to 20 weeks of gestation, as the fetus becomes large enough to be palpated and moved within the amniotic fluid.
  • ➤ External ballottement
  • ➤ 18 to 20 weeks

questions.text: The most accurate determination of gestational age in a pregnancy is by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CRL on ultrasound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Crown-Rump Length (CRL) on ultrasound, measured during the first trimester, is the most accurate method for determining gestational age , as fetal growth is consistent and predictable during this time.
  • ➤ Crown-Rump Length (CRL)
  • ➤ gestational age

questions.text: Twin to twin transfusion syndrome has various degrees of severity. This is classified by which staging?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Quintero staging

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Quintero staging system is used to classify the severity of Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS) , which affects monochorionic twin pregnancies. This staging system helps guide management based on the severity of the condition.
  • ➤ Quintero staging
  • ➤ Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)

questions.text: A 36-year-old lady was diagnosed to have monoamniotic monochorionic twins. She is now 33 weeks. What should be the plan of management?

options.label: D
options.text: Wait for spontaneous onset of labor

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Elective LSCS at 34 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In monoamniotic monochorionic twin pregnancies , elective cesarean section at 34 weeks is the recommended plan of management to reduce the risk of serious complications such as cord entanglement and fetal demise . Vaginal delivery and waiting for spontaneous labor are not recommended in these high-risk pregnancies.
  • ➤ monoamniotic monochorionic twin pregnancies
  • ➤ cesarean section at 34 weeks
  • ➤ cord entanglement
  • ➤ fetal demise
